message_1:
How many different sets of natural numbers are there that satisfy the following second-order logic sentence?

∃X ∀Y (Y ∈ X ↔ ∃Z (Y = 2Z))

Here, ∃ means "there exists", ∀ means "for all", ∈ means "is a member of", ↔ means "if and only if", and Z is a variable that can take on any value.
message_2:
The given second-order logic sentence can be translated as follows:

There exists a set X such that for all Y, Y is a member of X if and only if there exists a Z such that Y = 2Z.

This sentence describes a set X that contains all even natural numbers because Y is a member of X only if it can be written as 2 times some natural number Z.

Since the set of even natural numbers is unique, there is only 1 set of natural numbers that satisfies the given second-order logic sentence.
